articles.title: March 1978
articles.summary: This document outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) activities for March and April 1978, including general meetings with speakers on Space Telescopes and a 1977 eclipse cruise, various indoor and outdoor star parties, and board meetings. Events are hosted at several locations, emphasizing both member gatherings and public outreach opportunities like Astronomy Day.

articles.title: BLURBS
articles.summary: The astronomy club's 4Â½" telescope is available for use, and information is requested regarding the club's 2.4" refractor. An indoor star party on February 25th will serve as a planning session for the public Astronomy Day event at the Rosicrucian Museum. Additionally, a new McGlauflin is expected on March 5th.

articles.title: Editorial
articles.summary: The editor, Perry E. Forsterhoff, announces the renewal of his agreement for another six months, marking his sixth bulletin. He extends gratitude to numerous individuals who contributed to the bulletin's content and production, including Gerry Rattley, Jim Van Nuland, Ed Schell, John Rhodes, Cathy Pinheiro, and many others. Their diverse contributions ranged from articles and reports to logistical support, advertising, and general advice, all vital to the bulletin's success.

articles.title: GENERAL CLUB MEETINGS
articles.summary: This document announces general club meetings held on the first Friday of each month at 7:30 PM. The meetings take place at Mark Twain High School, located at 17421 Farley Rd. West in Los Gatos.

articles.title: DIRECTIONS FROM SAN JOSE
articles.summary: This document provides step-by-step driving directions from San Jose, California, to a specific location, likely a school. The route guides travelers via Highway 17 South, Lark Avenue, University Avenue, and Farley Road. It also includes an important note about Farley Road and the destination's driveway being unpaved, and that the school itself is not yet finished.

articles.title: EVERYONE WELCOME
articles.summary: This document provides an announcement for a board meeting scheduled for March 10 at 8:00 p.m. at Penny Pinschmidt's residence in Los Gatos. It includes detailed driving directions from San Jose, a small map, and a contact number for assistance, along with a warning about possible parking issues and a cryptic note: "Beware of the Fish."

articles.title: History
articles.summary: An indoor star party was held at the Los Gatos Red Cross on February 18th, featuring multiple telescopes, equipment work, and social interactions. Attendees set up various scopes, worked on a C8 mount and polished a mirror, and even pursued a humorous 'UFO' sighting that turned out to be a plastic bag. The event also included discussions on club activities, slide viewing, and lasted until 4:30 AM.

articles.title: Sanborn Canyon State Park - February 11th
articles.summary: An astronomy observing session at Sanborn Canyon State Park on February 11th was largely unsuccessful due to bad weather. Despite initial clear skies, clouds and rain moved in after sunset, leading many participants to pack up and leave. The remaining few discussed mundane topics until late evening, with astronomical observations limited to identifying only five stars and three planets.

articles.title: Notes from the board meeting in John Rhodes' motor home at Mark Twain on February 3rd. As reported by Debbie Moore.
articles.summary: The SJAA board convened on February 3rd, discussing future general meeting speakers, a potential meeting at Foothill Planetarium, and the AANC delegate's report on club dues. Key decisions included officially designating Mark Twain High School as the club's meeting place through June and setting calendar dates through May. The meeting was notably brief, lasting only 40 minutes.

articles.title: News Notez     by Gerry Rattley
articles.summary: Pioneer 11's trajectory was changed for a wider flyby of Saturn, outside its rings, to gather data for the future Voyager 2 Saturn-Uranus tour. Additionally, Carlton Perry modified an inverted fork telescope mount design from Astronomy magazine, incorporating Teflon bearings and triangular supports, making it a simple and easily built option for amateur astronomers.

articles.title: Red Spot Predictions
articles.summary: This article provides updated predictions for the Great Red Spot's meridian transits in March, improved by recent weather and new timings. The author, Jim Van Nuland, encourages observers to contact him with their own timings for comparison with theoretical data. A fudge factor has been applied to prevent anticipation.

articles.title: General Meeting, Febuary 3.
articles.summary: This document covers a general meeting where members discussed a new meeting location and heard presentations on advanced astrophotography techniques, including cold cameras and film sensitization. It also includes historical observations by Signor Cassini regarding Saturn's moons from 1677, and extensive lists of binary star data and orbital improvements for observers.

articles.title: ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION OF NORTHERN CALIFORNIA
articles.summary: The AANC President, Doug Berger, reflects on a successful 1977 for the Astronomical Association of Northern California, highlighting membership growth, a well-received joint conference, and widespread participation in Astronomy Day. He looks ahead to 1978, encouraging members to join upcoming Astronomy Day activities and announcing a major joint conference in July with several prominent astronomical organizations. The letter emphasizes member engagement for the continued success of west coast astronomy.
